item.title: How Reese Witherspoon Figured Out Who She Really Is
item.description: The actor and producer booked her first big role when she was 14 years old. More than 30 years later, she’s an entertainment-industry powerhouse.

item.title: This Easy Side Does Double Duty at Dinner
item.description: Parsnips dressed in miso and lemon, then topped with arugula and Parmesan can be a glorious accompaniment — or the whole meal.

item.title: Can You Use Your Spouse as a Hand Towel?

item.title: I’m Concerned About Sweatshops. Should It Change What I Buy?
item.description: How to balance a concern for human rights with concern for those depend on jobs in overseas factories?

item.title: The Filmmaker Who Finds the Humanity in History’s ‘Monsters’
item.description: Joshua Oppenheimer’s films show the political value of empathy in our polarized age.

item.title: Sean Penn Let Himself Get Away With Things for 15 Years. Not Anymore.
item.description: The actor and instigator is ready for his renaissance.

item.title: What the Public Memory of Charlie Kirk Revealed
item.description: For those who felt denigrated by his rhetoric, the bipartisan tributes to him as a champion of free speech augured something dangerous: the mainstreaming of formerly extremist views.
